fields.headline: News in brief
fields.bodyText: Mourners gather to say goodbye to Evel Knievel Mourners were gathering yesterday for the funeral of Evel Knievel, the motorcycle daredevil whose death-defying stunts and near-fatal crashes made him an international celebrity. Fireworks lit up the night sky over his hometown of Butte, Montana, with bursts of his trademark red, white and blue when the hearse carrying his body arrived in the town on Sunday. Pictures of Knievel were shown on a big screen and a sound system blared country music and Frank Sinatra's My Way. Knievel, who suffered from pulmonary fibrosis and diabetes, died on November 30 in Florida, aged 69. Associated Press in Butte Crocodiles kill 17 people in two weeks, TV reports Crocodiles killed 17 people in central Mozambique in the past two weeks, state television reported yesterday. The crocodiles attacked as people fetched water, washed clothes or fished in the Chinde river. "Something must be done to prevent the deaths in the river," Antonio Portugal, who said his uncle was killed by crocodiles, told state television. The authorities in the northwestern province of Tete, where crocodiles are also blamed for many deaths, have launched a campaign to collect crocodile eggs along the Zambezi river to control the reptiles' population. Associated Press in Maputo Football star jailed for 23 months over dogfighting Disgraced American football star Michael Vick, who pleaded guilty to his part in a dogfighting ring, was yesterday sentenced to 23 months in prison by a court in Richmond, Virginia. The former Atlanta Falcons quarterback, one of the National Football League's top players, pleaded guilty in August to a charge of conspiracy in connection with a dogfighting enterprise known as Bad Newz Kennels, in which underperforming dogs were shot, drowned, hanged or electrocuted. Vick, 27, told the court: "I would like to apologise to the court, to my family, to my kids, for what I have done." Associated Press in Richmond
